Posts.Content: Originally Posted by goatts Yes it would be crazy. That said, if it becomes unbearable you can always stop ADT but I would give it a shot. Don't let the list of SE's scare you away, but they tend to get worse over time. Have them do 3 month shots and evaluate it as you go. Tom I agree with Tom. Give ADT a try. It is fully reversible. Nothing drops PSA faster than getting rid of testosterone. Also, I would not listen to your doctor's survival prognosis statistics. Everybody is different. According to Sloan-Kettering Nomograms, I should have died 4 years ago. Furthermore, you might find that your quality of life will not suffer on ADT, it will just be different. I was diagnosed 6 years ago, at age 51, and have been on ADT for 5.5 years. At the time of diagnosis, I was a sexaholic, and my wife and I were VERY active in that department. I could not have imagined life without sex, but I wanted to live, and my wife wanted me to survive, as well. Now, I have zero sex, and zero sex drive, but I don't really miss it. My wife is perfectly fine with that, too. We're actually closer and more loving now than ever. ADT does have some other side effects, but they can be managed. I've found that daily Citalopram eliminated hot flashes and stabilized my mood, as well. I wish you all the best. - William

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pottk I am 8 months since surgery and still have no control . I am using 12 to 15 pads a day unless i use the alphadry condom catheter. The catheter has given me some resemblance to a normal life but there are still worries. At this with confirmation from my surgeon i have started the process of moving forward with having the AUS installed. Earlier this week i had a urodynamic test done not to sure what that will show but one thing is after my bladder was filled i could not stop the release. I don't want,to be centered around peeing my pants. I seldom use an incontinence pad, but rely almost entirely on a clamp. My favorite is the "J-Clamp," which has been recently discontinued. I wear the J-clamp 24/7, and only remove it for urination or showers. Other clamps, like the "Cunningham," are available, and Medicare will pay for them as well. Search online or call USI (Urological Supplies, Inc.) Address: 17051 Alico Commerce Ct, Suite 2, Fort Myers, Florida 33967 Phone: (239) 985-9327 Best of luck, William Satmary

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jebstart Thank you Lance, Fran, and Chuck for putting it in perspective. That is what I like about this board, experience, perspective, and encouragement. I will read this often! Jeb I'm 5 years post-op and still have incontinence. Pads were a pain and embarrassing. I recently discovered the J-clamp (google it). I bought one on eBay for about $50. It changed my life. Then I learned that insurance will pay. Call Urological Supplies Inc. at 855-730-4838 and they will FAX the form to your doctor and ship you the clamp. The clamp is designed break after about 90 days, but insurance pays for 1 clamp every three months. The J-clamp is a small flesh-colored collar that fits on your shaft, just behind the head. A rotating metal clip provides pressure to a ball at the underside of the shaft. Urine flow is restricted, but the collar is shaped to allow plenty of blood flow. It works like a charm!

Posts.Content: During a routine follow-up, doctors discovered an umbilical hernia. An MRI confirmed it, and also revealed an incisinal hernia from my robotic prostatectomy. A surgeon told me that I will eventually need both to be repaired surgically at some point. They don't bother me, so I'm putting off the surgery. I may die from PC before the hernias become problematic. My advice would be to have it checked out, so you know what you're dealing with. Originally Posted by shu246 Don't know. I had rt inguinal hernia repair at age 5, Lt. side at age 17, and both sides re-done about 2001. Then the area got worked over again last year with the prostatectomy. Some sharp single pains, like a pinch or needle poke, was something I had after the laproscopic work in 2001, but not after the prostatectomy. I put it down to surgical staples inside. Several times - every three or four months for a couple of years after the 2001 surgery, I would lift something wrong, or twist while lifting, and swear I'd sprung another hernia. But no, two or three weeks avoiding heavy work, and whatever was torn loose seemed to heal back. Actually it was about 1 year before I could sit for a long period without discomfort, and two years before I felt no more random pains or other problems. Same thing after the prostatectomy. Eight months out I thought I was cast iron again, and pushed up to 10 kilometers daily on the Concept 2 rowing machine. Then groin pains, rt testicle swelling, etc. Totally left off the rowing machine for two months, got an ultrasound of the area, and it's almost back to normal. Started ten days ago back on the rower with 2K, up to 6K now. Just don't push it, Steve. Gotta give it some time.

Posts.Content: Nicnic, A lot of good advice here. The best advice from me is FIND YOURSELF A PROSTATE ONCOLOGIST! I've been living with stage IV PC for five years now, and wish I could have a do-over. The best thing I did was finding a PC specialist - not a urologist - an Oncologist who specializes in PC. Mine is Dr. Mark Scholz in Marina Del Rey, CA. He's also the author of the book "Invasion of the Prostate Snatchers." Before him, my well-intentioned urologists made a LOT of mistakes. Of course, I did not know it at the time. A rapidly rising PSA is cause for concern; did they put you on Ciproflaxin to rule out infection? Gleason 6 is fairly low, but mine was 7 and already metastatic. Did anybody suggest doing a PET scan? A specialist can help in all of this. Please let us know your progress.

Posts.Content: I started Zytiga about nine months ago. A few months later I added Enzalutamide. I was shocked that my insurance would pay for both simultaneously. Eventually I discontinued Zytiga because it didn't seem to be helping, and my PSA started to relapse. Enzalutamide is not helping me now either, and I will probably stop it soon. The worst side effect for me with either or both drugs was general fatigue. Also, avoid large quanities of alcohol if you are on these drugs, or you will get the worst hangover of your life! Be advised that the pills are quite large for both medications. If you have difficulty swallowing pills, this could be a problem. Best wishes to you. I like the way you are planning ahead.

Posts.Content: My advice would be to get a consult from a prostate oncology specialist. My case was very similar to yours. I thought surgery or radiation were the only options. I picked surgery, only to find out post-op that the cancer had already spread to lymph nodes. Not to mention that I almost died on the table, and spent 3 weeks in the hospital due to post-op bleeds and infection (yes, this was with the Da Vinci robot). Eventually, I found a prostate oncologist (Dr. Mark Scholz, Marina Del Rey, CA), who immediately put me on hormone therapy and chemo. In hindsight, I should have insisted on getting PET scans to determine the extent of spread before the urologist started cutting. Five years later, I'm still alive, but PSA is rising again. I probably should have started hormone therapy immediately, and should have picked radiation instead of surgery, since I had to have radiation later anyway. Best wishes in making these critical decisions. Get a specialist on your team!

Posts.Content: For incontinence I use the J-clamp (google it). It works great! Medicare covers most of the cost. Call USI at 855-730-4838. As for impotence, my doctors lied me. Prior to surgery they bragged that they could "give an erection to a dead man." So I opted for the Non-nerve sparing surgery, which was a mistake, since they later learned that PC had already spread to lymph nodes. After a recovery period I tried injections (I forget the brand name). Injections gave me a partial erection, but it was excruciatingly painful, like a bad cramp. Then insurance bought me a fancy pump, which almost works, but the quality of the erection (if successful) was marginal. I never tried TriMix -- I was told that would be pain-free. Then I started hormone therapy and lost my libido. My wife lost hers, either out of sympathy for me or early menopause. So, we don't even try to have sex anymore. Cuddling works fine. I am 56 and she is 45. I've been battling with PC for five years. Prior to PC, we had a VERY, VERY active sex life (wink, wink, nudge, nudge...) So, either God is punishing me for my lustful youth, or he's telling me that I've already had enough sex for ten men, and it's time to call it quits. I'm still on HT, so I don't miss it much. I hope your experience is better than mine, but if not, it's not as bad as you might think.
